description:
This sample shows how a new object can be created.  There is not need to start with an object for JLio. With the add command the object can be created. 

The value can be anything, as long as it is a valid json notation. Even a function can be used . See samples with functions.
title: Create a new object with add

description:
This sample shows how a new property is added to an existing object. 
The value can be anything, as long as it is a valid json notation. Even a function can be used . See samples with functions.
title: Add a property to an existing object. (value: object)

description:
This sample shows how a new object can be created. There is not need to start with an object for JLio. With the add command the object can be created. In this case the value of tha add command didn't hold the entire object , but it uses the path notation to define the structure. 
If an path element doesn't exist the path will be created. All path elements exect the last element will be objects, so they can contain the property for the child elements. The last property will be given the actual value in the add command

The value can be anything, as long as it is a valid json notation. Even a function can be used . See samples with functions.
title: Create a new object using the JSON-path notation

description:
This sample shows how a property is set to new value
The value can be anything, as long as it is a valid json notation. Even a function can be used . 
See samples with functions.
title: Set property value on existing object

description:
This sample shows how multiple properties are set to new value using the .. notation of Json-path.
The value can be anything, as long as it is a valid json notation. In this case a function is used.
title: Set multiple properties with one set command (value:function)

description:
This sample shows how to add a property to all items in an existing array. 
All array items get the new property with the JSON-path notation [*].
title: Add a property to items in an array

description: This sample shows how to set a property to an item in an existing array. Not all array items get the new property due to the JSON-path notation [?(@.myItem==2)].
title: Set a property value to an item in an array using a filter

description:
This sample shows how to add a value to an existing array. The value can be a valid JSON notation. Even a function as a string is allowed. 
The command execution will add the value to the end of the existing array.
title: Add a value to an array

description: The array wil replaced with the value of the set command when the whole array is targeted with the path. The property to which the path points, in this case holds an array, will get the new value.
title: Set a property value to an array

description: With the copy command a new object can be created using the Json-Path notation in the toPath property.
title: Copy part of object to a new object

description: With the copy command a new object can be created using the Json-Path notation in the toPath property. The source reference will be removed. This can leave an object without any properties as shown in the example
title: move part of object to a new object

description: With the move command a element can be added to an array. If the destination is an Array the selected item(s) are added to the existing array. the source elements will be removed.
title: copy part of object to an array

description: With the move command a element can be added to an array. If the destination is an Array the selected item(s) are added to the existing array. the source elements will be removed.
title: Move part of object to an array

description:
The move command will take the sources  by the toPath property and place it into a array. This means that if the source is an array, this array will be added to the designation array as one item. If the arrays should be merged use the [*] notation.
See sample: Move items out an array into an existing array as separate items.
title: Move items out an array into an existing array as single item.

description:
The move command will take the sources  by the toPath property and place it into a array. This means that if the source is an array, this array will be added to the designation array as one item. If the arrays should be merged use the [*] notation.
See sample: Move items out an array into an existing array as separate items.
title: Move items out an array into an existing array as separate items.

description:
The copy command will take the sources  by the toPath property and place it into a array. This means that if the source is an array, this array will be added to the designation array as one item. If the arrays should be merged use the [*] notation.
See sample: Copy items out an array into an existing array as separate items.
title: Copy items out an array into an existing array as single item.

description:
The copy command will take the sources  by the toPath property and place it into a array. This means that if the source is an array, this array will be added to the designation array as one item. If the arrays should be merged use the [*] notation.
See sample: Copy items out an array into an existing array as separate items.
title: Copy items out an array into an existing array as separate items.

description:
The copy command will take the sources  by the toPath property and place it into a array. This means that if the source is an array, this array will be added to the designation array as one item. If the arrays should be merged use the [*] notation.
See sample: Copy items out an array into an existing array as single item.
title: Copy items out an array into an existing array as separate items with a filter.

description:
The move command will take the sources  by the toPath property and place it into a array. This means that if the source is an array, this array will be added to the designation array as one item. If the arrays should be merged use the [*] notation.
See sample: Move items out an array into an existing array as single item.
title: Move items out an array into an existing array as separate items with a filter.

description:
The copy command can create a new object using the JSON-Path notation on the "toPath" property. But if the target doesn't exist, the target will get the value of the source. When a single item is selected, the target will not be an array but the same single item. 
To add a copied value into an non existing array, the array needs to be created before the copy.
title: Copy singe value as an array when array doesn't exist

description:
The move command can create a new object using the JSON-Path notation on the "toPath" property. But if the target doesn't exist, the target will get the value of the source. When a single item is selected, the target will not be an array but the same single item. 
To add a moved value into an non existing array, the array needs to be created before the move.
title: Move singe value as an array when array doesn't exist

description:
The move command can create a new object using the JSON-Path notation on the "toPath" property. But if the target doesn't exist, the target will get the value of the source. When a multiple items are selected, the target will 
 add the value one after the other not creating an array. 
To add a moved values into an non existing array, the array needs to be created before the move.
title: Move multiple values as an array when array doesn't exist

description:
The copy command can create a new object using the JSON-Path notation on the "toPath" property. But if the target doesn't exist, the target will get the value of the source. When a multiple items are selected, the target will 
 add the value one after the other not creating an array. 
To add a copied values into an non existing array, the array needs to be created before the move.
title: Copy multiple values as an array when array doesn't exist

description: samples of the datetime function
title: Function DateTime

description: sample to create a guid and add it to a new object
title: function newGuid()

description:
The partial function allows to remove any unwanted ad even unknow properties from an object.

If the object only needs to contain certain properties, and the initial structure can vary, the partial function can help out a lot. 

The  same result can be achieved with multi commands. For instance; copy the desired properties to a new object and replace the initial value with newly created object.  

Another way could be to check the existence of a property that should be removed and remove it afterwards. 

Both solutions will work but with the partial function it is way more convenient.
title: Use partial function to get only the desired properties

description:
The partial function allows to remove any unwanted ad even unknow properties from an object.

If the object only needs to contain certain properties, and the initial structure can vary, the partial function can help out a lot. 

The  same result can be achieved with multi commands. For instance; copy the desired properties to a new object.  

Another way could be copy the object and than to check the existence of a property that should be removed and remove it afterwards. 

Both solutions will work but with the partial function it is way more convenient.
title: Use partial function to add only the desired properties from another object

description:
when a primitive needs to become an object, the promote function can help. 

In this sample the items in  an array get put into individual objects with a propertyname defined by the arguments of the promote function
title: Use promote function on all items in an array

description:
when a primitive needs to become an object, the promote function can help. 

In this sample the primitive type on an inputobject gets put into individual object with a property name defined by the argument of the promote function
title: Use promote function to promote primitive input object

description: in the sample two arrays are merged. it uses the the keys settings to indicate how the items in the arrays need to be identified.

inputObjects.name: first
second

OutputObjects.name: first
second

title: Merge two arrays with keys only values

description: This sample demonstrates adding nested objects with multiple properties using the add command. It shows how to create complex nested structures in a single operation.
title: Add nested object with multiple properties

description: This sample shows how to add an array to a new object. The array can contain primitive values or complex objects.
title: Add array to new object

description: This sample demonstrates adding a boolean value to an object. Boolean values are commonly used for flags and status indicators.
title: Add boolean property to object

description: This sample shows how to set multiple properties at once using separate set commands in a single script. Each property is updated independently.
title: Set multiple properties in sequence

description: This sample demonstrates setting a property value using a concat function to combine multiple string values.
title: Set property using concat function

description: This sample shows how to set an entire object to replace existing nested structure with a new one.
title: Set entire nested object

description: The put command adds or updates a property. If the property exists, it updates; if not, it creates. This sample shows put creating a new property.
title: Put new property to object

description: The put command can update existing properties. This sample demonstrates updating an existing value with put.
title: Put to update existing property

description: This sample shows using put with a function to set a timestamp. The put command works seamlessly with functions.
title: Put with datetime function

description: The remove command deletes a property from an object. This sample shows removing a single property.
title: Remove property from object

description: This sample demonstrates removing multiple properties from an object using the recursive descent operator (..).
title: Remove multiple properties with recursive path

description: This sample shows removing an item from an array using an index-based path.

title: Copy filtered array items

title: Move property between nested objects

description: This sample demonstrates moving multiple matching properties using a wildcard pattern.
title: Move collection to new location

description: This sample shows moving items between arrays with filtering to only move specific items.
title: Move filtered items between arrays

description: This sample demonstrates merging two simple objects, combining their properties.
title: Merge two objects

description: This sample shows merging arrays with a strategy to handle duplicates and maintain unique values.
title: Merge arrays with key-based matching

description: This sample demonstrates merging nested objects while preserving existing nested structure.
title: Merge nested configuration objects

description: This sample demonstrates using concat function to build a full address from multiple components.

OutputObjects.jsonString:
{
  "street": "123 Main St",
  "city": "Boston",
  "state": "MA",
  "zip": "02101",
  "fullAddress": "123 Main St, Boston, MA 02101"
}
OutputObjects.name: address

title: Concat for full address
